user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_linux_dev_dma_unmap:
```c
static void metal_linux_dev_dma_unmap(struct metal_bus *bus,
				      struct metal_device *device,
				      uint32_t dir,
				      struct metal_sg *sg,
				      int nents)
{
	struct linux_device *ldev = to_linux_device(device);
	struct linux_bus *lbus = to_linux_bus(bus);

	ldev->ldrv->dev_dma_unmap(lbus, ldev, dir, sg,
				       nents);
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_linux_dev_dma_unmap:
static struct linux_device *to_linux_device(struct metal_device *device)
{
	return metal_container_of(device, struct linux_device, device);
}
...
static struct linux_bus *to_linux_bus(struct metal_bus *bus)
{
	return metal_container_of(bus, struct linux_bus, bus);
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No parameter is modified in the provided code. The function metal_linux_dev_dma_unmap only reads its parameters to compute local pointers (via to_linux_device/to_linux_bus) and to pass them to ldev->ldrv->dev_dma_unmap. There are no assignments to any parameter variables, no increment/decrement operations, and no reassignments of pointer parameters (bus, device, sg) or value parameters (dir, nents). The helper functions shown (to_linux_device, to_linux_bus) return derived pointers but do not modify their pointer parameters. Therefore there are no fragments here that violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8.
